awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Protecting the Future of Children's Online Identities
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will investigate how children's online identities are established and managed as they grow up, especially in the context of technologies that facilitate indexing and resurfacing of personal data. Parents share extensive personal information about their children on social media sites, often starting before their children are even born. As a result, children are now growing up with their online identities formed and shaped from birth through adulthood. However, upon becoming adults, they have little ability to revise or remove what has already been posted about them online. Furthermore, computational advancements like tagging, facial recognition, and voice recognition enable searching and indexing of personal data, yet provide little support for families to make decisions about how that data should be preserved, accessed, or controlled. This work casts a lens on children's online identities as part of a complex sociotechnical system that is formed and shaped by parents, extended familial and social networks, technology companies, policy makers, and children themselves. 

This project will first investigate 1) what information families share about children online; 2) how families think about past identities and future identities being available online; and 3) technology companies' data management and archival practices around children. It will then 4) design and develop prototypes that support families making preservation, access, and control decisions about children's online identities. This research program bridges advances in computation, human-computer interaction, and social computing. It addresses numerous conceptual and technical challenges, including how to support preservation and access decisions about children's identities online, and how to support children's ownership of their own online identities as they grow up. This project includes partnerships with nonprofit agencies to educate families about social media use and sharing personal information online.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project was motivated by growing concerns about parents sharing personal information about their children online. At the time this project was conceptualized, around 2014-2015, parents had become very active on Facebook and were sharing a lot of content about their children online. The same now happens on Instagram, Reddit, TikTok, and elsewhere. This project first examined parent sharing behaviors, especially when anonymous, and the disclosure and privacy implications of that sharing. The project then pivoted to focus on the problem of online harassment, among both youth and adults. There it focused on what kinds of harms are associated with harassment, and what kinds of remedies people prefer.

We found that when parents go to Reddit, they are more likely to discuss potentially stigmatizing topics using anonymous ("throwaway") accounts, and that this is a useful feature for them. On average, throwaway comments are more likely to receive a response, receive more responses that are longer, and receive responses that have higher karma scores than topically similar comments posted by non-throwaway accounts. We also found gender differences, with mothers posting more about babies and early childhood whereas fathers’ engagement increases as the children age, and with certain topics such as custody.

As we pivoted to focus on bullying and harassment experiences online, we found distinct differences between young people and adults. Young people primarily want apologies if they experience harassment or bullying, perhaps to maintain social relationships with their peers. In contrast, adults prefer content removal and banning users, perhaps because they have weaker ties in their online interactions. In terms of types of harassment, we found greater perceived harm associated with non-consensual photo sharing, doxxing, and reputational damage compared to other types of harassment. However, in our study of 14 different countries around the world, we found that insults and rumors were perceived as more harmful outside of the U.S., especially harm to family reputation. We also found that women perceive greater harm associated with online harassment than men, on average, in every country we studied.

A theme that persisted throughout this project was a focus on data rights and data privacy, especially for marginalized groups who might experience greater threats. In many of our studies, we chose to examine demographic differences in our analyses (e.g. how women experience harassment versus how men do) because we felt those differences need to be understood and addressed by both designers and policymakers. As a whole, this project built up a body of literature with a commitment to equity and justice on social media. It also supported numerous students who participated in the research, many of whom are in groups who are underrepresented and/or excluded in technology fields.


Last Modified: 08/14/2023
Modified by: Sarita Y Schoenebeck
